key_channel_insights.line_content: OTAs priced above the airline site on 98.2 % of itineraries last week, with a modest +0.5 % average premium.
Metasearch undercut the website on 96.0 % of itineraries, yet the discount averaged only –0.08 %, keeping revenue dilution minimal.
GDS displayed higher fares on 98.9 % of itineraries, at a +0.59 % average markup, mirroring OTA behaviour but via indirect distribution.

conclusion.line_content: This report provides a high-level summary of the price discrepancies observed across different channels.  It is important to note that the data contains many nuances depending on various factors such as market conditions, booking windows, and the competitive landscape. Understanding these subtleties can be critical in optimizing pricing strategies and ensuring competitive positioning.

As part of our 'PriceEye' solution, we are developing an intuitive dashboard designed to help your airline's analysts drill down into this data. This tool will allow you to uncover and focus on critical actionable insights, enabling your team to make data-driven decisions with confidence.

We are here to support you in leveraging these insights to enhance your revenue management and distribution strategies. Please don't hesitate to connect with our team for more information about how PriceEye can assist you in achieving your business objectives.

ota_highlights.line_content: 98.2 % of monitored itineraries were higher-priced on OTAs than on the airline site, leaving virtually no fare parity or undercuts.
Average OTA premium is +0.5 % overall (from +0.03 % long-haul to +0.65 % on far-out bookings).
Website fares were missing on 1.8 % of itineraries—up 69 % WoW—mainly close-in and non-Poland origins.

ota_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: OTA-higher status covers 98.2 % of ODs; the +0.5 % price delta is stable MoM.
Website fare absence on OTA rose to 1.8 % (+69 % WoW), the first material uptick this month.
Exact price matches fell to 0 % last week, confirming near-total loss of fare parity.
No instances of OTAs pricing below the website for three consecutive weeks.

ota_summary_by_region.line_content: On seven short-haul ODs, OTAs priced higher 98.0 % of the time at a +0.55 % premium; missing fares doubled WoW to 2.0 %.
All long-haul itineraries showed an OTA mark-up, albeit a negligible +0.03 %.

ota_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: For PL departures, 98.7 % of fares were higher on OTA with a +0.56 % uplift; coverage gap limited to 1.3 %.
Outside Poland, OTA-higher share eased to 94.6 %; premium shrank to +0.07 %, but missing fares spiked to 5.4 %.

ota_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: Within 0-14 days, OTAs marked up 97.4 % of itineraries by +0.44 %; availability misses surged 96 % WoW to 2.6 %.
Beyond 60 days, every fare was dearer on OTA, showing the steepest premium at +0.65 % with full availability.

mse_highlights.line_content: Metasearch priced lower than the website on 96.0 % of ODs, a stable trend week over week.
Average undercut is just –0.08 %, signalling near-parity and limited revenue impact.
Outside Poland, MSE priced higher 3.5 % of the time—five-fold the PL rate—and ‘lower’ share slipped 5 ppts WoW.

mse_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: MSE could not replicate the website fare in 0.7 % of cases, a 23 % uptick WoW but still below last month.
Exact price match remains rare at 2.7 % of ODs.
Lower pricing accounts for 96.0 % of ODs with a –0.08 % gap; share basically flat WoW.
Premium cases dropped to 0.7 % of itineraries, averaging +0.73 %.

mse_summary_by_region.line_content: MSE was lower on 95.8 % of short-haul routes, discount –0.08 % and trend steady.
On limited long-haul data, ‘MSE Higher’ surfaced in 2.3 % of cases, yet 97.7 % still showed an undercut (–0.05 %).

mse_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: For PL origins, MSE undercut 96.4 % of fares; over-pricing occurred in only 0.3 %.
‘MSE Higher’ rose to 3.5 % and ‘MSE Lower’ dropped to 91.2 %, signalling elevated risk outside home market.

mse_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: MSE lower on 95.2 % of itineraries; premium cases fell 65 % WoW to 0.6 % with a –0.07 % discount.
MSE lower on 97.8 % (–0.8 ppt WoW); new 0.8 % premium cases emerged while the discount deepened to –0.09 %.

gds_highlights.line_content: GDS priced higher than the website on 98.9 % of itineraries; no undercuts observed.
Average GDS premium is +0.59 %, rising to +0.76 % on far-out bookings but only +0.04 % on long-haul.
Higher-priced share dipped 0.68 ppts WoW, shifting into ‘offer not found’ rather than parity.

gds_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: GDS failed to return the airline fare on 1.12 % of ODs, up 0.68 ppts WoW but commercially negligible.
No identical prices across any dimension, confirming absence of true GDS parity.
Zero instances of GDS undercutting the website last week, unchanged MoM.
Higher fares in 98.9 % of ODs with a +0.59 % premium; incidence eased slightly WoW.

gds_summary_by_region.line_content: GDS higher on 98.8 % with +0.65 % premium; incidence down 0.75 ppts WoW.
100 % higher pricing but negligible +0.04 % uplift, steady over time.

gds_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: 99.5 % higher pricing at +0.65 % premium; stable pattern.
94.6 % higher pricing with a slim +0.10 % premium; higher-fare share fell 3.6 ppts WoW.

gds_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: GDS higher on 98.4 % with +0.51 % premium; incidence eased 0.96 ppts WoW.
100 % higher pricing with the largest +0.76 % premium; remains universal despite 1.4 ppt MoM drop.
